_comment: Species-specific spot recommendations for Durham County birding

brdowl.habitat_specific: Mature bottomland hardwood forest with large trees (>12" DBH), especially oaks and tulip poplars. Prefers areas near streams or swampy lowlands with dense understory.
brdowl.detection_tips: Listen for distinctive 'who-cooks-for-you' call, especially Feb-Apr during breeding. Check for whitewash on tree trunks. Most vocal 30 min after sunset.

spots.why_here: Mature riparian forest along Eno River with large oaks and quiet evening atmosphere
Old-growth hardwoods with large tree cavities, minimal disturbance
Dense bottomland forest with stream corridor, known nesting area

easowl1.habitat_specific: Mixed deciduous and pine forest edges, especially areas with old woodpecker holes or natural cavities. Tolerates suburban parks with mature trees.
easowl1.detection_tips: Listen for descending whinny call or monotone trill. Often responds to playback (use sparingly). Check tree cavities and nest boxes at dawn.

spots.why_here: Forest edge habitat with mature trees and open areas, good cavity availability
Mixed pine-hardwood forest with numerous snags and cavities

woothr.habitat_specific: Interior deciduous forest with dense understory and leaf litter. Prefers moist slopes with shrub layer, especially near streams. Needs >20 acres of contiguous forest.
woothr.detection_tips: Listen for flute-like 'ee-oh-lay' song at dawn. Most vocal May-Jun. Forages on ground in leaf litter. Look for bird flipping leaves.

spots.why_here: Large contiguous forest tract with stream corridors and dense understory
Mature forest interior with moist ravines and good understory
Riparian forest with dense understory vegetation

kenwar.habitat_specific: Moist ravines in mature deciduous forest with dense understory of spicebush, pawpaw, or similar shrubs. Needs thick ground-level vegetation.
kenwar.detection_tips: Listen for loud 'churry-churry-churry' song from understory. Skulks in dense vegetation. Most vocal May-Jun. Often sings from low perch.

spots.why_here: Moist ravines with dense spicebush understory, classic Kentucky Warbler habitat
Low-lying areas along streams with thick understory growth

pilwoo.habitat_specific: Large tracts of mature forest (>100 acres) with abundant standing dead trees and fallen logs. Requires large trees for foraging and nesting.
pilwoo.detection_tips: Listen for loud 'kuk-kuk-kuk' call or drumming on hollow trees. Look for large rectangular excavations in dead trees. Loud and conspicuous.

spots.why_here: Largest contiguous forest in Durham with mature trees and snags
Mature bottomland forest with many dead trees from past flooding

virrai.habitat_specific: Freshwater marshes with emergent vegetation (cattails, bulrushes). Needs standing water with dense cover. Very secretive.
virrai.detection_tips: Listen for descending 'kid-ick, kid-ick' call. Rarely seen, responds to playback in breeding season. Best detected by call at dawn/dusk.

spots.why_here: Marsh edges with cattails and emergent vegetation

louwat.habitat_specific: Rocky streams in forested ravines. Needs clear, fast-flowing water with exposed rocks and boulders. Highly site-faithful.
louwat.detection_tips: Listen for loud, ringing song echoing off water. Often bobs tail while walking on rocks. Arrives early Mar, departs by Aug.

spots.why_here: Rocky stream sections with clear flowing water and forested banks

amewoo.habitat_specific: Moist forest edges and young forest with damp leaf litter. Uses fields for display flights at dusk. Probes soil for earthworms.
amewoo.detection_tips: Listen for 'peent' call and twittering display flight at dusk Feb-Apr. Check damp areas after rain. Display flights occur over open fields adjacent to forest.

spots.why_here: Forest edge with adjacent open fields, perfect for display flights
Open areas near moist forest edges

nswowl.habitat_specific: Dense coniferous or mixed forest with thick understory. Winter visitor that roosts in dense cover, often near tree trunks.
nswowl.detection_tips: Very secretive winter visitor. Listen for repeated 'toot' calls at night Nov-Feb. Check dense cedar groves and holly thickets for roosting birds.

spots.why_here: Mixed forest with dense pine and cedar groves for roosting

reshaw.habitat_specific: Mature forest near water - streams, swamps, or bottomlands. Nests in deciduous trees, hunts from perches along forest edges and clearings.
reshaw.detection_tips: Listen for loud 'kee-aah' scream. Often soars over forest calling. Check exposed perches along forest edges. Active year-round.

spots.why_here: Forested bottomlands along river with hunting perches
Forest edge along lake with open hunting areas
